title.narrative: F.a: South Caucasus: Supporting Peace Process Competences of Government Officials in Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia

description.narrative: Twenty years after the dismantling of the Soviet Union, the South Caucasus is still searching for a conflict settlement framework that will satisfactorily address the ambiguous status of the secessionist regions of Abkhazia, South Ossetia and Nagorno-Karab akh. As the experience in the South Caucasus peace processes shows, the approaches to this complex environment relying on traditional diplomatic instruments have generated only standardized approaches to peace processes leading to rather fragile outcomes a nd a stalemate in the peace talks. The lack of knowledge of basic concepts and core competencies in peace process design at executive levels is acute and is reflected on every other aspect of the peace-making attempts in the region. In addition, there is n o meaningful debate and discussion internally on the possible ways towards resolution of the conflict. A structured peace mediation capacity building and coaching process is needed for key actors in conflict resolution executive positions and actors strate gically advising members of the Armenian, Azerbaijani and Georgian governments actively involved in the official peace process. The project supports Track 1 actors in Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia to improve their competence in better understanding peace process design that can have long-lasting effects in the peace processes in the region.The project will provide in-depth exposure to lessons learned from international best practices and sequenced immersion in concrete case-studies will allow for both ref lection and applied learning practice, while creating a space where key actors from relevant executive agencies can engage together in ?out of the format? brainstorming about the processes that they are responsible for directly. In the same manner, the pos sibility to exchange ideas in a safe and familiar environment encourages an organic search for potential solutions and strategies and will enable in the long term the development of an internal demand for more informed multi-track international support.
